subject: HIST
name: Honors: Global Societies
info: Sweep of history, from prehistoric societies to dawn of modern world circa 1500. Forces that pushed humans to explore new environments and develop higher levels of social organization and cross-cultural interaction.

subject: HIST
name: Honors: Age of Global Contact
fullname: Honors: The Age of Global Contact
info: Five centuries of globalization. How the modern, interconnected world came into being. Changing material life (food, clothes, petroleum) and ideologies/beliefs. Analysis of primary documents to show how historical knowledge is produced.

subject: HIST
name: Honors:  Globalization
info: Increased global interconnections over past 50 years. Impact of information revolution on human rights, economic inequality, ecological challenges, and decolonization. Cases in Asia, Africa, Latin America, or Middle East.

subject: HIST
name: Honors: Europe & the World, I
fullname: Europe and the World: Expansion, Encounter, and Exchange to 1500
info: Europe in the making, from Hammurabi to Columbus. Heyday of ancient Near East, Late Middle Ages. Culture. European interactions with wider world through religion, conquest, and trade. Beginning of the age of discoveries.

subject: HIST
name: Honors: Europe & the World, II
fullname: Europe and the World: Expansion, Encounter, and Exchange From 1500 to Present
info: Emergence of a Europe of nations/empires. Transformations through revolutions, wars, and encounters with world regions.

subject: HIST
name: Honors:  American Hist to 1865
fullname: Authority and Rebellion:  American History to 1865
info: Conflict/change, from colonial era through Civil War. Colonization/resistance, slavery, nation-building, westward expansion, gender roles, religion, reform, race/ethnicity, immigration, industrialization, class relations. Students use primary sources, historical scholarship.

subject: HIST
name: Honors: U.S. Hist Since 1865
info: U.S. history since Civil War, in global context. Emancipation. Forms of labor. Immigration. Citizenship. Conceptions of race/gender. Hot/cold wars. Reform/rights movements. Globalization. State power. Students use primary sources, historical scholarship.

subject: HIST
name: Honors Latin America-1825
info: Societies of Americas, Spain, and Portugal before contact. Interactions among Native Americans, African slaves, and Europeans, from colonization through independence. Religion, resistance, labor, gender, race. Primary sources, historical scholarship.

subject: HIST
name: Honors:East Asia 1500-Present
fullname: Honors: From Subjects to Citizens: The History of East Asia from 1500 to the Present
info: How Asian states, societies, economies, cultures linked with one another/European powers. Historical effects. Covers India, China, Japan, Korea, Indochina.

subject: HIST
name: Religion and US Culture Wars
fullname: Religion and the American Culture Wars
info:
Thomas Jefferson, Benjamin Franklin, James Madison, Thomas Paine, George Washington, and John Adams on religion, faith, and religion in politics. Deism. Enlightenment-era discussions about rational religion. Rise of evangelicalism.
Separation of church/state, framers' original intent for first amendment. Religious Right.

subject: HIST
name: Jr Honors Seminar
info: Intended for History honors majors in their junior year, the course is run as a seminar, with emphasis on readings and discussion. Weekly sessions focus on selected topics relating to historical method and historiography.

subject: HIST
name: Honors: How to Do History
info:
Skills/research experience to complete senior paper. How to answer questions such as, "What is history?" How to locate/use historical sources, develop thesis, and turn rough idea into full research proposal.

prereq: History major or dept consent

subject: HIST
name: Honors: Capstone Research
info:
The capstone research course helps students prepare and complete their writing intensive research paper that satisfies the capstone requirement of the History Major. Class readings and exercises help students define a research question that fits within the thematic frame of the course, conceptualize the project, identify and analyze primary sources, craft a paper outline, revise drafts, and produce a final version of the Major Paper in History. Topics in 4011W/V will vary by semester and will be printed in the class schedule. 

prereq: Jr or sr history major, honors, or instr consent

subject: HIST
name: Honors:  Major  Paper
info:
Research paper on topic of student's choice. Work largely with primary sources. Faculty guidance.

prereq: Department Consent Required

subject: HIST
name: Undergraduate Honors Prosem
info:
Themes vary depending on the instructor. Reading/discussion of historiography/methodology, research.

prereq: [Jr or sr], honors
